Great work with this!!!

Steve Howell (showell) said:

My personal pet peeve with Zulip is that we donâ€™t have a dialog box when you create a topic. Maybe we save the user from an extra mouse click or tap on the enter key. But we have a confusing experience where we literally sacrifice having a dialog with the user.

Interesting. I'm personally not too bothered about that so far, but I can see potential for improvement (especially for new and non-technical users) and you make a good point and I agree. I know we're getting off-topic, so maybe we can strike up the conversation somewhere else, but what if instead of the composer box permanently hanging down the bottom there is a button that opens a dialog box (similar to composing an email) that provides contextual options for better work flow? It could increase some slight screen real estate (maybe), potentially lessen confusion about creating a new topic (or replying to the current one), and the great work that's been done to the editor re markdown toolbars/tooltips could all go in...

Just thinking out loud... something like this... ?

What SoGo looks like:

Example-SoGo.gif

Brainstorm sketches...

Example-Zulip-ComposeButton.jpg

Example-Zulip-ComposeDialog.jpg

PS if a moderator wants to move this post to a different topic, that's probably a good idea!

@Jore These are great! They definitely appeal to me, especially the third. I also like your take on the green pencil icon, which I think would at least be intuitive to Twitter users. I am curious what Alya Abbott thinks here.

I realize now that @Jore had already split out a new topic for this. (I had moved his message from an off-topic topic before I was caught up.)

I'll leave his mockups here for context, and then I'm gonna show what happens when you follow the docs to create a new topic.
First, I'll note that the "New Topic" button has no help button, so I'm gonna google for the docs.
Here are the docs: https://zulip.com/help/start-a-new-topic

Well, there's not much there of substance:

image.png

I'll start here:

image.png

I'll click on New Topic and see this:

image.png
And now I'm on my own, but I'll do the most obvious things.
Quick aside: when you tab-enter to the Send button, the new purple color makes it hard to see the button is selected.

And then I see this, and there's no obvious keyboard support:

image.png
I can't see the message that I sent, and I am still in the old narrow.
I shift-tab back five times and hit enter to select the new topic narrow, and then I'm happy.
One thought here is that we could at least pop a modal after I hit send to ask me if I want to narrow to the new topic (default) or stay in the old narrow.

My main observations here are:

  • we don't have a way to discover the user docs
  • we don't have good user docs for this confusing operation
  • we don't have good keyboard support
  • it's overall clumsy

Yeah when I first started using Zulip it took a while to understand the composer. It's a different UI but also not totally intuitive, especially when introducing people to the concept of topics. Sounds like there is already great work going on in the background to tidy this up, which is great.
I think a more simple layout could be the better way to go, and yeah, give people some more familiarity with concepts they already know and understand like composing an email, etc.

I would be interested in somehow removing/replacing the "New topic" and "New private message" buttons. Now that we have a wide button that opens the compose box, I hardly ever click "New topic". I just click the wide button and edit the topic name. The pencil icon would be one approach, though I'd be inclined to still keep the wide button too.

The modal idea is a separate question... I guess one thing I want to be mindful of is preserving a fairly lightly-weight "this is a chat message" feel, vs. a "I'm composing an email" feel. Zulip messages are a bit heavier than Slack/Discord/etc. already, but I'm wary of moving too far into the forum/email direction.
All really good points.
Yeah, I'm also wary of a modal, since it prevents you from looking at existing content while composing your new topic.

Sure, I get that concern. Would this suggestion make it more obvious that the bottom is a composer window though? i.e. Buttons to initiate actions?
And then when clicked, the composer window bumps up, just like how it does now?

We put a lot of thought into the bottom row / close compose box reply design, and recently changed it after much discussion from a label like the above. I think the current model is a lot better, because it makes more clear to the user what clicking that button will actually do, without introducing potentially confusing terminology like "to current topic".
